case_vignette: an 8-year-old male presents with 1 week of itchy blisters on the ears. he just recently returned from spring break with his family. he denies using any particular products on the ears before the rash. he says that this has occurred yearly for the last several years, always around the same time. he denies proximal muscle weakness. he denies flaking in the scalp.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have itchy blisters on my ears that have been there for about a week.
Have you noticed similar symptoms on any other parts of your body?
No, the symptoms are only on my ears.
Do these blisters contain fluid, and have any of them burst?
Yes, the blisters contain fluid, but they haven't burst.
Do you have a history of allergies or skin conditions?
No, I don't have any history of allergies or skin conditions.
Have you started using any new personal care products or been exposed to new environments recently?
No, I haven't started using any new products on my ears before the rash appeared.
Have you been exposed to extreme temperatures or direct sunlight recently?
Yes, I just returned from spring break with my family, which typically involves exposure to sunlight.
Final Diagnosis: Polymorphic Light Eruption (PMLE)
